name: Verify.Maybe
comment:
Functions to verify properties of a Maybe.

@docs isJust

values.name: isJust
values.comment:
Fails if a Maybe is Nothing.

    isJust "error" Nothing
    --> Err [ "error" ]


    isJust "error" (Just 42)
    --> Ok 42 -- It removes the wrapper as well!

name: Verify.List
comment:
Functions to verify properties of a List.

@docs notEmpty

values.name: notEmpty
values.comment:
Fails if a List is empty.

    notEmpty "error" []
    --> Err [ "error" ]

    notEmpty "error" [1]
    --> Ok [1]

name: Verify.String
comment:
Functions to verify properties of a String.

@docs notBlank, minLength, maxLength, isInt

values.name: isInt
values.comment:
Fails if a String is not an Int. It will return the Int in the result.

    isInt "error" "a"
    --> Err [ "error" ]

    isInt "error" "42"
    --> Ok 42

values.name: maxLength
values.comment:
Fails if a String is smaller than a given maximum.

    maxLength 3 "error" "abc"
    --> Ok "abc"

    maxLength 3 "error" "abcd"
    --> Err [ "error" ]
values.type: Int -> error -> Verify.Validator error String String

values.name: minLength
values.comment:
Fails if a String is smaller than a given minimum.

    minLength 3 "error" "ab"
    --> Err [ "error" ]

    minLength 3 "error" "abc"
    --> Ok "abc"
values.type: Int -> error -> Verify.Validator error String String

values.name: notBlank
values.comment:
Fails if a String is blank (empty or only whitespace).

    notBlank "error" ""
    --> Err [ "error" ]

name: Verify.Dict
comment:
Functions to verify properties of a Dict.

@docs notEmpty

values.name: notEmpty
values.comment:
Fails if a Dict is empty.

    import Dict

    notEmpty "error" <| Dict.empty
    --> Err [ "error" ]

    notEmpty "error" <| Dict.fromList [ (1, 1) ]
    --> Ok <| Dict.fromList [ (1, 1) ]
values.type: error -> Verify.Validator error (Dict.Dict a b) (Dict.Dict a b)

name: Verify.Set
comment:
Functions to verify properties of a Set.

@docs notEmpty

values.name: notEmpty
values.comment:
Fails if a Set is empty.

    import Set

    notEmpty "error" <| Set.empty
    --> Err [ "error" ]

    notEmpty "error" <| Set.fromList [ (1, 1) ]
    --> Ok <| Set.fromList [ (1, 1) ]

name: Verify
comment:
Verify allows you to validate a model into a structure that makes forbidden states impossible.

@docs Validator, ok, fail, verify, keep, custom, andThen, when

aliases.name: Validator
aliases.comment:
This is just an alias for a function from an input to a result.
The result is either:

  - contains a list of all errors that didn't satisfy the given spec.
  - contains an resulting structure.

values.name: andThen
values.comment:
This allows you to combine multible Validators.

    import Verify.Maybe exposing (isJust)
    import Verify.String exposing (notBlank)


    validator { firstName = Nothing }
    --> Err [ "You need to provide a first name." ]

    validator { firstName = Just "   " }
    --> Err [  "You need to provide a none empty first name." ]

    validator { firstName = Just "Stöffel" }
    --> Ok "Stöffel"

    validator : Validator String { a | firstName : Maybe String } String
    validator =
        Verify.ok identity
            |> verify .firstName verifyName

    verifyName : Validator String (Maybe String) String
    verifyName =
        isJust "You need to provide a first name."
            |> andThen (notBlank "You need to provide a none empty first name.")
values.type: Verify.Validator error result finally -> Verify.Validator error input result -> Verify.Validator error input finally

values.name: custom
values.comment:
Sometimes the verification of a part only makes sense in a bigger context.
This means your Validator needs access to the whole structure.

    import Verify.Maybe exposing (isJust)


    validator : Validator String { a | username : Maybe String, level: Int, strength: Int } (String, Int)
    validator =
        Verify.ok (,)
            |> verify .username (isJust "You need to provide a username.")
            |> custom (\{level, strength} ->
                if strength > level then
                    Err [ "Your strength can exceed your level." ]
                else
                    Ok strength
                )


    validator { username = Just "Ork1", level = 3, strength = 5 }
    --> Err [ "Your strength can exceed your level." ]

    validator { username = Just "Ork1", level = 6, strength = 5 }
    --> Ok ("Ork1", 5)

    validator { username = Nothing, level = 3, strength = 5 }
    --> Err [ "You need to provide a username."
    -->     , "Your strength can exceed your level."
    -->     ]
values.type: Verify.Validator error input result -> Verify.Validator error input (result -> finally) -> Verify.Validator error input finally

values.name: fail
values.comment:
Allows you to create a failing Validator.

    fail "always fail" Nothing
    --> Err [ "always fail" ]

values.name: keep
values.comment:
You can use `keep` if you want a value to be in the verified structure without any verification.

    import Verify.Maybe exposing (isJust)


    validator : Validator String { a | id : Int, firstName : Maybe String } (Int, String)
    validator =
        Verify.ok (,)
            |> keep .id
            |> verify .firstName (isJust "You need to provide a first name.")


    validator { id = 1, firstName = Nothing }
    --> Err [ "You need to provide a first name." ]

    validator { id = 1, firstName = Just "Stöffel" }
    --> Ok (1, "Stöffel")
values.type: (bigger -> smaller) -> Verify.Validator error bigger (smaller -> finally) -> Verify.Validator error bigger finally

values.name: ok
values.comment:
This allows you to lift any value into a validator.
This is particularly useful to initialize a pipeline.

    ok "always ok" Nothing
    --> Ok "always ok"

values.name: verify
values.type: (bigger -> smaller) -> Verify.Validator error smaller result -> Verify.Validator error bigger (result -> finally) -> Verify.Validator error bigger finally

values.name: when
values.comment:
Fails if a predicate is False.

    when hasInitial "error" ""
    --> Err [ "error" ]

    when hasInitial "error" "Christoph"
    --> Ok 'C'

    hasInitial : String -> Maybe Char
    hasInitial str =
        case String.uncons str of
            Just (initial, _) -> Just initial
            Nothing -> Nothing
values.type: (input -> Maybe.Maybe result) -> error -> Verify.Validator error input result
